title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: software augmentedRCBD built R statistical programming language add-(‘package’ R lingua franca). performs analysis data generated experiments augmented randomised complete block design according Federer, W.T. (1956a, 1956b, 1961; 1976). also computes analysis variance, adjusted means, descriptive statistics, genetic variability statistics etc. includes options data visualization report generation. tutorial aims educate users utilising package performing analysis. Utilising augmentedRCBD data analysis requires basic knowledge R programming language. However, many intended end-users may familiar R, sections 2 4 give ‘gentle’ introduction R, especially aspects necessary get augmentedRCBD running performing data analysis Windows environment. Users already familiar R can feel free skip section 5.

text: Expressions instructions form code entered > prompt console. Expressions can constant, arithmetic condition. advanced useful expression function call (see section 4.3). code: # Constant 123 [1] 123 # Arithmetic (add two numbers) 1 + 2 [1] 3 # Condition 34 > 25 [1] TRUE 1 == 2 [1] FALSE # Function call (mean of a series of numbers) mean(c(25,56,89,35)) [1] 51.25 # Assign the result of the expression 1 + 2 to an object 'a' a <- 1 + 2 a [1] 3

title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: R object-oriented programming language (OOP). kind construct created R ‘object’. object ‘class’ (shown using class() function) different ‘attributes’ defines operations can done object. different types data structure objects R vectors, matrices, factors, data frames, lists. ‘function’ also object, defines procedure sequence expressions.

title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: vector collection elements single type (‘mode’). common vector modes ‘numeric’, ‘integer’, ‘character’ ‘logical’. c() function used create vectors. functions class(), str() length() show attributes vectors. Vector modes ‘numeric’ stores real numbers, ‘integer’ stores integers, can enforced suffixing elements ‘L’. vector mode ‘character’ store text. vector mode ‘logical’ stores ‘TRUE’ ‘FALSE’ logical data.
code: # A numeric vector a <- c(1, 2, 3.3) class(a) [1] "numeric" str(a) num [1:3] 1 2 3.3 length(a) [1] 3 # An integer vector b <- c(1L, 2L, 3L) class(b) [1] "integer" str(b) int [1:3] 1 2 3 length(b) [1] 3 # A character vector c <- c("one","two","three") class(c) [1] "character" str(c) chr [1:3] "one" "two" "three" length(c) [1] 3 #logical vector d <- c(TRUE,TRUE,TRUE,FALSE,TRUE,FALSE) class(d) [1] "logical" str(d) logi [1:6] TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE TRUE FALSE length(d) [1] 6

title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: ‘factor’ R stores data categorical data variables different levels. character, numeric integer vector can transformed factor using .factor() function.
code: catg <- c("male","female","female","male","male") catg [1] "male"   "female" "female" "male"   "male" is.factor(catg) [1] FALSE # Apply the factor function factor_catg <- factor(catg)  factor_catg [1] male   female female male   male   Levels: female male is.factor(factor_catg) [1] TRUE class(factor_catg) [1] "factor" str(factor_catg) Factor w/ 2 levels "female","male": 2 1 1 2 2 # Conversion of numeric to factor a <- c(1, 2, 3.3) class(a) [1] "numeric" str(a) num [1:3] 1 2 3.3 fac_a <- as.factor(a) class(fac_a) [1] "factor" str(fac_a) Factor w/ 3 levels "1","2","3.3": 1 2 3 # Conversion of integer to factor b <- c(1L, 2L, 3L) class(b) [1] "integer" str(b) int [1:3] 1 2 3 fac_b <- as.factor(b) class(fac_b) [1] "factor" str(fac_b) Factor w/ 3 levels "1","2","3": 1 2 3 # Conversion of character to factor c <- c("one","two","three") class(c) [1] "character" str(c) chr [1:3] "one" "two" "three" fac_c <- as.factor(c) class(fac_c) [1] "factor" str(fac_c) Factor w/ 3 levels "one","three",..: 1 3 2

text: ‘data frame’ R special kind list every element equal length. important handling tabular data R. array like structure rows columns. column needs single data type, however data type can vary columns.
code: L <- LETTERS[1:4] y <- 1:4 z <- c("This", "is", "a", "data frame") df <- data.frame(L, x = 1, y, z) df L x y          z 1 A 1 1       This 2 B 1 2         is 3 C 1 3          a 4 D 1 4 data frame str(df) 'data.frame':   4 obs. of  4 variables:  $ L: chr  "A" "B" "C" "D"  $ x: num  1 1 1 1  $ y: int  1 2 3 4  $ z: chr  "This" "is" "a" "data frame" attributes(df) $names [1] "L" "x" "y" "z"  $class [1] "data.frame"  $row.names [1] 1 2 3 4 rownames(df) [1] "1" "2" "3" "4" colnames(df) [1] "L" "x" "y" "z"

title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: work R done functions. object defining procedure takes one objects input (‘arguments’), performs action finally gives new object output (‘return’). class(), mean(), getwd(), +, etc. functions. example function mean() takes numeric vector argument returns mean numeric vector. user can also create custom functions. example function foo adds two numbers gives result.
code: a <- c(1, 2, 3.3) mean(a) [1] 2.1 foo <- function(n1, n2) {   out <- n1 + n2   return(out) } foo(2,3) [1] 5

title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: addition numbers text, special elements can included different data objects. NA (available) indicates missing data. Inf indicates infinity. NaN (Number) indicates undefined value.
code: x <- c(2.5, NA, 8.6) y <- c(TRUE, FALSE, NA) z <- c("k", NA, "m", "n", "o") is.na(x) [1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE is.na(z) [1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE anyNA(x) [1] TRUE a [1] 1.0 2.0 3.3 is.na(a) [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE 1/0 [1] Inf 0/0 [1] NaN

title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: [ function used extract elements object indexing (numeric logical). Named elements lists data frames can extracted using $ operator. Consider vector . Consider matrix m. Consider list w. Consider data frame df.
code: a <- c(1, 2, 3.3, 2.8, 6.7) # Numeric indexing # Extract first element a[1] [1] 1 # Extract elements 2:3 a[2:3] [1] 2.0 3.3 # Logical indexing a[a > 3] [1] 3.3 6.7 m <- matrix(1:9, nrow = 3, ncol = 3, byrow = TRUE) colnames(m) <- c('a', 'b', 'c') m a b c [1,] 1 2 3 [2,] 4 5 6 [3,] 7 8 9 # Extract elements m[,2] # 2nd column of matrix [1] 2 5 8 m[3,] # 3rd row of matrix a b c  7 8 9 m[2:3, 1:3] # rows 2,3 of columns 1,2,3 a b c [1,] 4 5 6 [2,] 7 8 9 m[2,2] # Element in 2nd column of 2nd row b  5 m[, 'b'] # Column 'b' [1] 2 5 8 m[, c('a', 'c')] # Column 'a' and 'c' a c [1,] 1 3 [2,] 4 6 [3,] 7 9 w <- list(vec = a, mat = m, data = df, alist = list(b, c))  # Indexing by number w[2] # As list structure $mat      a b c [1,] 1 2 3 [2,] 4 5 6 [3,] 7 8 9 w[[2]] # Without list structure a b c [1,] 1 2 3 [2,] 4 5 6 [3,] 7 8 9 # Indexing by name w$vec [1] 1.0 2.0 3.3 2.8 6.7 w$data L x y          z 1 A 1 1       This 2 B 1 2         is 3 C 1 3          a 4 D 1 4 data frame df L x y          z 1 A 1 1       This 2 B 1 2         is 3 C 1 3          a 4 D 1 4 data frame # Indexing by number df[,2] # 2nd column of data frame [1] 1 1 1 1 df[2] # 2nd column of data frame x 1 1 2 1 3 1 4 1 df[3,] # 3rd row of data frame L x y z 3 C 1 3 a df[2:3, 1:3] # rows 2,3 of columns 1,2,3 L x y 2 B 1 2 3 C 1 3 df[2,2] # Element in 2nd column of 2nd row [1] 1 # Indexing by name df$L [1] "A" "B" "C" "D" df$z [1] "This"       "is"         "a"          "data frame"

title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: genetic variability statistics mean, phenotypic, genotypic environmental variation (Federer Searle (1976)), phenotypic, genotypic environmental coefficient variation (Burton (1951), Burton (1952)), category phenotypic genotypic coefficient variation according Sivasubramaniam Madhavamenon (1973), broad-sense heritability (H2) (Lush (1940)), H2 category according Robinson (1966), Genetic advance (GA), genetic advance per cent mean (GAM) GAM category according Johnson et al. (1955) computed object class augmentedRCBD follows. Genetic variability analysis needs performed sum squares “Treatment: Test” significant. Negative estimates variance components computed abnormal. information deal , refer Robinson et al. (1955) Dudley Moll (1969).

what: 8 Data Analysis for a Multiple Traits
title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: Analysis data multiple traits simultaneously can performed using augmentedRCBD.bulk function. generates object class augmentedRCBD.bulk. object can taken input print.augmentedRCBD.bulk print results console. results can also exported MS Word report using report.augmentedRCBD.bulk function.  Fig. 8. Workflow analysis multiple traits augmentedRCBD.

previous_headings: 8 Data Analysis for a Multiple Traits
title: Data Analysis with `augmentedRCBD`
text: Consider data frame data imported Table 1 according instructions section 4.8. Rather performing analysis individually variable/trait separately using augmentedRCBD, analysis can performed simultaneously traits using augmentedRCBD.bulk function. wrapper around augmentedRCBD core function associated helper functions. However case treatment comparisons/grouping least significant difference Tukey’s honest significant difference method computed. Also output object size reduced using simplify = TRUE argument augmentedRCBD function. logical arguments describe, freqdist gva can used specify whether generate descriptive statistics, frequency distribution plots genetic variability statistics respectively. gva = TRUE, plots compare phenotypic genotypic coefficient variation, broad sense heritability genetic advance mean traits also generated.

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Designs
text: Functions analysis data generated experiments augmented randomised complete block design according Federer, W.T. (1961) doi:10.2307/2527837. Computes analysis variance, adjusted means, descriptive statistics, genetic variability statistics etc. includes data visualization report generation functions.

code: # Install from CRAN install.packages('augmentedRCBD', dependencies=TRUE) # Install development version from Github if (!require('devtools')) install.packages('devtools') devtools::install_github("aravind-j/augmentedRCBD")

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design for Multiple Traits/Characters — augmentedRCBD.bulk
text: augmentedRCBD.bulk wrapper around functions augmentedRCBD, describe.augmentedRCBD, freqdist.augmentedRCBD gva.augmentedRCBD. carry analyses multiple traits/characters input data data frame object.

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design for Multiple Traits/Characters — augmentedRCBD.bulk
code: augmentedRCBD.bulk(   data,   block,   treatment,   traits,   checks = NULL,   check.inference = c("overall", "traitwise"),   alpha = 0.05,   describe = TRUE,   freqdist = TRUE,   gva = TRUE,   k = 2.063,   check.col = "red",   console = TRUE )

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design for Multiple Traits/Characters — augmentedRCBD.bulk
text: data data data frame object. data frame possess columns specifying block, treatment multiple traits/characters. block Name column specifying blocks design character string. treatment Name column specifying treatments character string. traits Name columns specifying multiple traits/characters character vector. checks Character vector checks present treatment levels. can also named list character vector checks trait traits column. list names trait names. specified, checks inferred data basis number replications treatments/genotypes. check.inference method inference checks checks specified. Either "overall" infer checks basis trait data "traitwise" infer checks basis trait separately. alpha Type error probability (Significance level) used multiple comparisons. describe TRUE, descriptive statistics computed. Default TRUE. freqdist TRUE, frequency distributions plotted. Default TRUE. gva TRUE, genetic variability analysis done. Default TRUE. k standardized selection differential selection intensity required computation Genetic advance. Default 2.063 5% selection proportion (see Details gva.augmentedRCBD). Ignored gva = FALSE. check.col colour(s) used highlight check values plot character vector. Must valid colour values R (named colours, hexadecimal representation, index colours [1:8] default R palette() etc.). console TRUE, output printed console. Default TRUE.

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design for Multiple Traits/Characters — augmentedRCBD.bulk
text: list class augmentedRCBD.bulk containing following   components: Details Details augmented design used   traits/characters. ANOVA, Treatment Adjusted data   frame mean sum squares, p value stastical significance   specified traits treatment adjusted ANOVA. ANOVA, Block   Adjusted data frame mean sum squares, p value stastical   significance specified traits block adjusted ANOVA Means data frame adjusted means treatments   specified traits. Check statistics list data   frames check statistics number replications, standard   error, minimum maximum value alpha Type error   probability (Significance level) used. Std. Errors data   frame standard error difference various combinations   specified traits. CD data frame critical difference (  specified alpha) various combinations specified   traits. Overall adjusted mean data frame overall   adjusted mean specified traits. CV data frame   coefficient variance specified traits. Descriptive statistics data frame descriptive statistics   specified traits. Frequency distribution list   ggplot2 plot grobs frequency distribution plots. k standardized selection differential selection   intensity used computaton Genetic advance. Genetic variability analysis data frame genetic   variability statistics specified traits. GVA plots   list three ggplot2 objects plots () Phenotypic   Genotypic CV, (b) Broad sense heritability (c) Genetic advance   mean warnings list warning messages () captured   model fitting, frequency distribution plotting genetic   variability analysis.

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design for Multiple Traits/Characters — augmentedRCBD.bulk

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design — augmentedRCBD
text: augmentedRCBD function analysis variance augmented randomised block design (Federer, 1956; Federer, 1961; Searle, 1965) generation well comparison adjusted means treatments/genotypes.

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design — augmentedRCBD
code: augmentedRCBD(   block,   treatment,   y,   checks = NULL,   method.comp = c("lsd", "tukey", "none"),   alpha = 0.05,   group = TRUE,   console = TRUE,   simplify = FALSE,   truncate.means = TRUE )

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design — augmentedRCBD
text: block Vector blocks (factor). treatment Vector treatments/genotypes (factor). y Numeric vector response variable (Trait). checks Character vector checks present treatment levels. specified, checks inferred data basis number replications treatments/genotypes. method.comp Method comparison treatments ("lsd" least significant difference "tukey" Tukey's honest significant difference). "none", comparisons made, ANOVA output given data frame adjusted means computed directly treatment block effects instead using emmeans. alpha Type error probability (Significance level) used multiple comparisons. group TRUE, genotypes grouped according "method.comp". Default TRUE. console TRUE, output printed console. Default TRUE. Default TRUE. simplify TRUE, ANOVA output given data frame instead summary.aov object. Default TRUE. truncate.means TRUE, negative adjusted means truncated zero. Default TRUE.

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design — augmentedRCBD
text: list class augmentedRCBD containing following  components: Details Details augmented design used. Means data frame "Means", "Block", "SE", "Mix",  "Max" "Adjusted Means" "Treatment". ANOVA,  Treatment Adjusted object class summary.aov ANOVA table  treatments adjusted. ANOVA, Block Adjusted object  class summary.aov ANOVA table block adjusted. Block effects vector block effects. Treatment effects vector treatment effects. Std. Errors data frame standard error difference  various combinations along critical difference tukey's  honest significant difference (method.comp = "tukey")  alpha. Overall adjusted mean Overall adjusted mean. CV Coefficient variation. Comparisons data  frame pairwise comparisons treatments. computed  argument group TRUE Groups data frame  compact letter display pairwise comparisons treatments. Means  least one letter common significantly different statistically.  computed argument group TRUE warning vector warning messages () captured  model fitting.

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design — augmentedRCBD
text: function borrows code DAU.test function agricolae package (de Mendiburu et al., 2016) well Appendix VIII Mathur et al., (2008).

title: Analysis of Augmented Randomised Complete Block Design — augmentedRCBD
text: Data preferably balanced .e. check  genotypes present blocks. , warning issued. missing values. number test  genotypes can vary within block. case large number treatments genotypes, advisable  avoid comparisons group =  FALSE argument  memory processor intensive. advised simplify output  simplify = TRUE order reduce output object size.

text: list following descriptive statistics: Mean  mean value. PV Phenotyic variance. GV Genotyipc variance. EV Environmental variance. GCV Genotypic coefficient  variation GCV category \(GCV\) category according  Sivasubramaniam Madhavamenon (1973) . PCV Phenotypic coefficient variation PCV category  \(PCV\) category according  Sivasubramaniam Madhavamenon (1973) . ECV Environmental coefficient variation hBS  broad-sense heritability (\(H^{2}\))  (Lush 1940) . hBS category  \(H^{2}\) category according  Robinson (1966) . GA Genetic advance  (Johnson et al. 1955) . GAM Genetic  advance per cent mean  (Johnson et al. 1955) . GAM category  \(GAM\) category according  Johnson et al. (1955) .

title: Perform Genetic Variability Analysis on augmentedRCBD Output — gva.augmentedRCBD
text: gva.augmentedRCBD performs genetic variability analysis ANOVA results object class augmentedRCBD computes several variability estimates. phenotypic, genotypic environmental variance (\(\sigma^{2}_{p}\), \(\sigma^{2}_{g}\) \(\sigma^{2}_{e}\) ) obtained ANOVA tables according expected value mean square described Federer Searle (1976) follows: \[\sigma^{2}_{g} = \sigma^{2}_{p} - \sigma^{2}_{e}\] Phenotypic genotypic coefficients variation (\(PCV\) \(GCV\)) estimated according Burton (1951, 1952) follows: \[GCV = \frac{\sigma^{2}_{g}}{\sqrt{\overline{x}}} \times 100\] \(\overline{x}\) mean. estimates \(PCV\) \(GCV\) categorised according Sivasubramanian Madhavamenon (1978) follows: broad-sense heritability (\(H^{2}\)) calculated according method Lush (1940) follows: \[H^{2} = \frac{\sigma^{2}_{g}}{\sigma^{2}_{p}}\] estimates broad-sense heritability (\(H^{2}\)) categorised according Robinson (1966) follows: Genetic advance (\(GA\)) estimated categorised according Johnson et al., (1955) follows: \[GA = k \times \sigma_{g} \times \frac{H^{2}}{100}\] constant \(k\) standardized selection differential selection intensity. value \(k\) 5% proportion selected 2.063. Values \(k\) selected proportions available Appendix Table Falconer Mackay (1996). Selection intensity (\(k\)) can also computed R : p proportion selected individuals, deviation truncation point mean (x) selection intensity (k) follows: x = qnorm(1-p) k = dnorm(qnorm(1 - p))/p Using Appendix Table Falconer Mackay (1996) can recreated follows. Appendix Table (Falconer Mackay, 1996) p% selected percentage individuals population, x deviation point truncation selected individuals population mean selection intensity. Genetic advance per cent mean (\(GAM\)) estimated categorised according Johnson et al., (1955) follows: \[GAM = \frac{GA}{\overline{x}} \times 100\]
code: TableA <- data.frame(p = c(seq(0.01, 0.10, 0.01), NA,                            seq(0.10, 0.50, 0.02), NA,                            seq(1, 5, 0.2), NA,                            seq(5, 10, 0.5), NA,                            seq(10, 50, 1))) TableA$x <- qnorm(1-(TableA$p/100)) TableA$i <- dnorm(qnorm(1 - (TableA$p/100)))/(TableA$p/100)

text: raw values augmentedRCBD object rounded 2   digits word excel reports. However, case excel report,   raw values present cell formatted display 2   digits. , values adjusted means used downstream   analysis, export raw values within R use excel report. default rounding can changed setting global options   augmentedRCBD.round.digits. example   setOption(augmentedRCBD.round.digits = 3) sets number decimal   places rounding 3. title: Generate MS Word or Excel Report from augmentedRCBD.bulk Output — report.augmentedRCBD.bulk
code: # Example data blk <- c(rep(1,7),rep(2,6),rep(3,7)) trt <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 11, 12, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 9, 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 6, 10)  y1 <- c(92, 79, 87, 81, 96, 89, 82, 79, 81, 81, 91, 79, 78, 83, 77, 78, 78,         70, 75, 74) y2 <- c(258, 224, 238, 278, 347, 300, 289, 260, 220, 237, 227, 281, 311, 250,         240, 268, 287, 226, 395, 450) dataf <- data.frame(blk, trt, y1, y2)  bout <- augmentedRCBD.bulk(data = dataf, block = "blk",                            treatment = "trt", traits = c("y1", "y2"),                            checks = NULL, alpha = 0.05, describe = TRUE,                            freqdist = TRUE, gva = TRUE,                            check.col = c("brown", "darkcyan",                                          "forestgreen", "purple"),                            console = FALSE) #>  #> ANOVA for y1 computed (1/2) #>  #> ANOVA for y2 computed (2/2)  # \donttest{ report.augmentedRCBD.bulk(aug.bulk = bout,                           target = file.path(tempdir(),                                              "augmentedRCBD bulk output.docx"),                           file.type = "word") #> File created at /var/folders/bp/kmfmhnl95kx1c8x321z7twbw0000gn/T//RtmpYgg6iT/augmentedRCBD bulk output.docx report.augmentedRCBD.bulk(aug.bulk = bout,                           target = file.path(tempdir(),                                              "augmentedRCBD bulk output.xlsx"),                           file.type = "excel") #> Error in insertImage(wb = wb, sheet = sheet, file = fileName, width = width,     height = height, startRow = startRow, startCol = startCol,     units = units, dpi = dpi): File does not exist. # }

title: Generate MS Word or Excel Report from augmentedRCBD Output — report.augmentedRCBD
text: aug object class augmentedRCBD. target path report file created. file.type file type report. Either "word" MS Word report file "excel" MS Excel report file. k standardized selection differential selection intensity  required computation Genetic advance. Default 2.063 5%  selection proportion (see Details gva.augmentedRCBD). Ignored gva = FALSE. check.col colour(s) used highlight check values plot character vector. Must valid colour values R (named colours, hexadecimal representation, index colours [1:8] default R palette() etc.).

title: Generate MS Word or Excel Report from augmentedRCBD Output — report.augmentedRCBD
text: raw values augmentedRCBD object rounded 2   digits word excel reports. However, case excel report,   raw values present cell formatted display 2   digits. , values adjusted means used downstream   analysis, export raw values within R use excel report. default rounding can changed setting global options   augmentedRCBD.round.digits. example   setOption(augmentedRCBD.round.digits = 3) sets number decimal   places rounding 3. Values rounded zero, instead rounded nearest   decimal place. F value, t ratio p values rounded less 3   decimal places.

title: Generate MS Word or Excel Report from augmentedRCBD Output — report.augmentedRCBD
code: # Example data blk <- c(rep(1,7),rep(2,6),rep(3,7)) trt <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 11, 12, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 9, 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 6, 10) y1 <- c(92, 79, 87, 81, 96, 89, 82, 79, 81, 81, 91, 79, 78, 83, 77, 78, 78,         70, 75, 74) y2 <- c(258, 224, 238, 278, 347, 300, 289, 260, 220, 237, 227, 281, 311, 250,         240, 268, 287, 226, 395, 450) data <- data.frame(blk, trt, y1, y2) # Convert block and treatment to factors data$blk <- as.factor(data$blk) data$trt <- as.factor(data$trt) # Results for variable y1 (checks inferred) out <- augmentedRCBD(data$blk, data$trt, data$y1, method.comp = "lsd",                       alpha = 0.05, group = TRUE, console = FALSE)  # \donttest{ report.augmentedRCBD(aug = out,                      target = file.path(tempdir(),                                         "augmentedRCBD output.docx"),                      file.type = "word",                      check.col = c("brown", "darkcyan",                                    "forestgreen", "purple")) #> Warning: P-value for "Treatment: Test" is > 0.05. Genetic variability analysis may not be appropriate for this trait. #> File created at /var/folders/bp/kmfmhnl95kx1c8x321z7twbw0000gn/T//RtmpYgg6iT/augmentedRCBD output.docx report.augmentedRCBD(aug = out,                      target = file.path(tempdir(),                                         "augmentedRCBD output.xlsx"),                      file.type = "excel",                      check.col = c("brown", "darkcyan",                                    "forestgreen", "purple")) #> File created at /var/folders/bp/kmfmhnl95kx1c8x321z7twbw0000gn/T//RtmpYgg6iT/augmentedRCBD output.xlsx # }

title: augmentedRCBD 0.1.8
text: report.augmentedRCBD.bulk - Fixed issue use “DF” trait name duplication “Df” “Degrees freedom” column name. Fixed warning messages GVA. print.augmentedRCBD.bulk - Fixed warning messages GVA. augmentedRCBD.bulk, print.augmentedRCBD.bulk, report.augmentedRCBD.bulk - Updated handle unequal number treatments (checks tests) among traits. augmentedRCBD.bulk - Replaced depreceated ggplot2 arguments.
